question: What is U.S. duty drawback?
answer: U.S. duty drawback is a program that refunds exporters and importers up to 99 percent of the duties they paid when importing goods into the U.S. It aims to promote U.S. commerce and manufacturing by allowing U.S. products to compete internationally without the burden of import duties.
title: What Is U.S. Duty Drawback? Meaning and Benefits Explained
description: Discover how the U.S. duty drawback program allows importers and exporters to recover up to 99% of duties paid, promoting American commerce and global competitiveness.

question: What are the main types of U.S. duty drawback?
answer: The three main types of U.S. duty drawback are: Manufacturing (for goods manufactured or produced in the U.S. using imported, duty-paid merchandise), Unused (for merchandise not used in the U.S. prior to exportation), and Rejected (for duty-paid merchandise that does not meet specifications or is defective).
title: Main Types of U.S. Duty Drawback: A Complete Guide
description: Learn about the three principal U.S. duty drawback types—Manufacturing, Unused, and Rejected—and how each applies to refunded import duties.

question: What documents are required for a U.S. duty drawback claim?
answer: For importing, required documents include Entry Summary (CF 7501), Commercial Invoice, and Certificate of Delivery (CF 7552). For exporting, required documents include Commercial Invoice, Bill of Lading, and Export Waiver.
title: Required Documents for a U.S. Duty Drawback Claim
description: Find out what documents are needed for U.S. duty drawback claims, including import and export paperwork for a smooth and successful filing.

question: Where can I file a U.S. duty drawback claim?
answer: U.S. duty drawback claims can be filed at designated centers in Chicago, Houston, New York/Newark, and San Francisco.
title: Where to File a U.S. Duty Drawback Claim
description: See the designated U.S. locations where you can submit duty drawback claims, including Chicago, Houston, New York/Newark, and San Francisco.

question: How can I speed up the U.S. duty drawback process?
answer: Submitting duty drawback bonds and using electronic submissions via the Automated Broker Interface (ABI) can expedite the process. Accelerated payment options are also available to receive refunds faster.
title: How to Speed Up the U.S. Duty Drawback Process
description: Explore tips to expedite your U.S. duty drawback, including electronic filing, duty drawback bonds, and using accelerated payment options.

question: Are Section 301 duties eligible for drawback in the US?
answer: Yes, Section 301 duties are eligible for drawback, along with other duties such as Merchandise Processing Fees (MPF) and Harbor Maintenance Taxes (HMF).
title: Are Section 301 Duties Eligible for U.S. Duty Drawback?
description: Learn which duties qualify for U.S. drawback, including Section 301, Merchandise Processing Fees (MPF), and Harbor Maintenance Taxes (HMF).

question: Can I file for drawback on past transactions in the US?
answer: Yes, you can file for drawback on import and export transactions that occurred over the past five years, provided the qualifying export date is after the import date.
title: Can You Claim U.S. Duty Drawback on Past Transactions?
description: Understand the time limits and conditions for filing duty drawback on past U.S. import and export transactions.

question: How much does a duty drawback service cost in the US?
answer: In the US, the cost is typically a competitive percentage of the duty recovered, depending on factors such as the duty recovery levels, statutory filing provision, and administrative resources required.
title: How Much Does U.S. Duty Drawback Service Cost?
description: Discover the typical pricing structure for U.S. duty drawback services and what factors influence the cost of recovery.

question: What percentage of duties does CBP (US Customs) refund?
answer: U.S. Customs and Border Protection refunds 99% of the duties, fees, and taxes paid.
title: What Percentage of U.S. Duties Does CBP Refund?
description: See how much U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) refunds under the duty drawback program, including fees and taxes.

question: How long does it take to receive a drawback refund in the US?
answer: With accelerated payment, refunds can be received within 30 days from the date of filing. Without accelerated payment, it could take one year or longer.
title: U.S. Duty Drawback Refund Timeline: How Long Does It Take?
description: Find out how quickly you can expect a duty drawback refund in the U.S. with and without accelerated payment options.

question: If I can claim duty drawback myself, what does Trade Duty Refund bring to the process?
answer: While it is possible to claim duty drawback yourself, the process is complex and can be very lengthy for non-specialists. Trade Duty Refund and its partners have decades of experience in this field and will help optimize the process both in financial value and in time. Additionally, Trade Duty Refund provides duty reclaim solutions in different regions around the world, making it a one-stop shop for cross-border e-commerce merchants looking to benefit from higher cash flow and returned goods logistics cost savings. For more insights on duty refunds, duty-free returns, and international trade, contact Trade Duty Refund.
title: Why Use Trade Duty Refund for Duty Drawback Claims?
description: Discover the advantages Trade Duty Refund brings to duty drawback claims, including expertise, global solutions, faster processing, and increased financial benefits for e-commerce businesses.

question: What is nearshoring to Free Trade Agreement Countries?
answer: Nearshoring to Free Trade Agreement (FTA) countries involves relocating business processes or manufacturing operations to countries that have a free trade agreement with the company's home country. This strategy is often adopted to take advantage of the benefits offered by FTAs, such as reduced tariffs, simplified customs procedures, and improved market access. Companies in the U.S. might nearshore to Mexico or Canada to take advantage of the USMCA.
title: What Is Nearshoring to Free Trade Agreement Countries?
description: Understand the concept of nearshoring to FTA countries, its business advantages, and how agreements like USMCA support market access and reduced trade barriers.

question: What is section 301 (aka Trump Tariffs)?
answer: Section 301 of the Trade Act of 1974 is a provision of U.S. trade law that authorizes the President to take action, including the imposition of tariffs, to enforce U.S. rights under trade agreements and to respond to certain unfair trade practices by foreign countries. The term 'Trump Tariffs' refers to the tariffs imposed by the Trump administration under this authority. During his mandates, Donald Trump used Section 301 to impose tariffs on a wide range of goods, particularly targeting China. These tariffs were intended to address issues such as intellectual property theft and forced technology transfer. The tariffs affected billions of dollars worth of goods, including steel, aluminum, and a variety of consumer products.
title: What Is Section 301 (Trump Tariffs)? History and Explanation
description: Learn about Section 301 of the Trade Act, the so-called Trump Tariffs, and how these trade actions impacted imports, targeting issues such as IP theft and unfair practices.

question: What is a Free Trade Zone (FTZ)?
answer: A Free Trade Zone (FTZ) is a designated area within a country where goods can be imported, handled, manufactured, reconfigured, and re-exported without the intervention of CBP, the US customs authorities.
title: What Is a Free Trade Zone (FTZ)? Definition and Benefits
description: Explore what a Free Trade Zone is and how FTZs facilitate import, export, and manufacturing activities with reduced customs intervention and enhanced efficiency.

question: What is a bonded warehouse?
answer: A bonded warehouse is a secure facility where imported goods can be stored, manipulated, or undergo manufacturing operations without payment of duty. It is authorized by customs authorities and allows for the deferral of duty payments until the goods are released into the market. This setup is particularly useful for businesses that need to store goods for extended periods before selling or distributing them, as it helps in managing cash flow and reducing upfront costs.
title: What Is a Bonded Warehouse? Definition and Business Benefits
description: Find out how bonded warehouses work, why they are used for deferring duty payments, and how they improve cash flow for businesses with imported goods.

question: What is the First Sale Rule?
answer: This rule allows importers to use the price paid for the goods in an earlier sale (often the first sale from the manufacturer to a middleman) rather than the price paid in the last sale (from the middleman to the importer) for the purpose of calculating customs duties. Contact us for more detail on applicability, requirements and documentation.
title: What Is the First Sale Rule in U.S. Customs?
description: Understand the First Sale Rule, how it allows use of an earlier transaction value for duty calculation, and the requirements for importers to use this cost-saving method.

question: What is the standard method for determining shipment value for imported goods?
answer: The standard method is based on the price actually paid or payable for imported goods when sold for export to the United States.
title: How Is Shipment Value Determined for U.S. Imports?
description: Learn the standard method U.S. Customs uses to determine shipment value—based on the price paid or payable for exported goods.

question: What value should E-Commerce sellers use when declaring the value of goods sold to end consumers?
answer: In a B2C model, eCommerce sellers must use the final retail price as the declared value when making a sale to an end consumer.
title: What Value Should E-Commerce Sellers Declare for End Consumer Goods?
description: Find out why e-commerce sellers must declare the final retail price for goods sold direct to consumers in customs documentation.

question: Are there any exceptions where E-Commerce sellers can use the cost price instead of the retail price for customs declaration?
answer: Yes, one exception is if the seller has implemented a fully-fledged 'First Sale' program. This requires proper documentation and procedures for bona-fide, arms-length transactions occurring prior to the final sale to the end consumer.
title: Exceptions Allowing E-Commerce Sellers to Use Cost Price for Customs
description: Explore when e-commerce sellers can declare cost price instead of retail price for customs, and the documentation needed for the First Sale Rule exception.

question: What is a B2C refund solution and how can it benefit my e-commerce business?
answer: A B2C refund solution streamlines the process of refunding customers for returned goods, especially in cross-border transactions. It can enhance customer satisfaction, reduce operational costs, and improve cash flow by automating and simplifying the refund process.
title: What Is a B2C Refund Solution for E-Commerce?
description: Learn how a B2C refund solution works, benefits e-commerce businesses, and improves cross-border returns, cash flow, and customer satisfaction.

question: How can cross-border retailers efficiently manage duty refunds?
answer: Cross-border retailers can manage duty refunds efficiently by partnering with specialized service providers who offer automated solutions for tracking, claiming, and processing duty refunds. This ensures compliance with international regulations and maximizes recovery of duties paid.
title: Efficient Duty Refund Management for Cross-Border Retailers
description: Learn how cross-border retailers can use automated solutions and specialist partners to streamline duty refund claims, ensure compliance, and boost duty recovery.

question: How can I reclaim duties for my e-commerce business operating in Europe?
answer: To reclaim duties in Europe, you need to follow the specific procedures outlined by the customs authorities in the countries where you operate. This typically involves submitting detailed documentation and proof of export or destruction of goods.
title: How to Reclaim Duties for E-Commerce in Europe
description: Step-by-step guide for e-commerce businesses on reclaiming duties in Europe, including required documentation, export records, and country-specific procedures.

question: What is international duty reclaim, and how can my business benefit from it?
answer: International duty reclaim is the process of recovering duties paid on goods that are re-exported or destroyed. By reclaiming these duties, your business can reduce costs and improve profitability, especially in high-volume cross-border transactions.
title: International Duty Reclaim: Definition and Benefits
description: Discover the advantages of international duty reclaim and how recovering paid duties on re-exported goods can boost profitability for cross-border businesses.

question: How do duty-free returns work for e-commerce businesses?
answer: Duty-free returns allow customers to return goods without incurring additional duties or taxes. This can be a significant selling point for cross-border e-commerce businesses, as it simplifies the return process and enhances customer satisfaction.
title: How Duty-Free Returns Work for E-Commerce
description: Explore how duty-free returns enable seamless cross-border returns, reduce extra taxes, and improve customer satisfaction for online retailers.

question: Why should I consult with e-commerce experts for duty-related issues?
answer: E-commerce experts specialize in navigating the complexities of international trade, including duty refunds, drawback, and compliance. Their expertise can help you optimize your operations, reduce costs, and avoid potential pitfalls.
title: Why Consult E-Commerce Experts for Duty Refunds?
description: Find out how consulting e-commerce and customs experts helps businesses navigate duty refunds, improve compliance, and avoid costly errors.

question: What steps are involved in reclaiming duties for my business?
answer: Reclaiming duties typically involves identifying eligible goods, gathering necessary documentation, submitting claims to the relevant customs authorities, and following up to ensure timely processing and approval.
title: Steps for Reclaiming Duties in Your Business
description: Learn the key steps to successfully reclaim duties for your business, from identifying applicable goods to claim submission and documentation.

question: How can I calculate duty drawback for my e-commerce business?
answer: Calculating duty drawback involves determining the duties paid on imported goods, tracking the export or destruction of those goods, and applying the relevant drawback rates. Specialized software or service providers can automate and simplify this process.
title: How to Calculate Duty Drawback for E-Commerce
description: Methods and tools for calculating duty drawback for e-commerce, including software solutions, process automation, and key formulas.

question: What are the key considerations for managing duty refunds in the apparel and sporting goods sectors?
answer: Key considerations include understanding the specific duty rates and regulations for apparel and sporting goods, maintaining accurate records of imports and exports, and leveraging technology to streamline the refund process.
title: Duty Refund Management for Apparel & Sporting Goods
description: Explore essential tips for securing duty refunds in the apparel and sporting goods industries, from regulation knowledge to leveraging technology and accurate record-keeping.

question: Who can apply for a repayment of import duties in the UK?
answer: You can apply if you are an importer or their representative, an agent, a freight forwarder, or a private individual.
title: Who Is Eligible for Import Duty Repayment in the UK?
description: Find out who can apply for import duty repayment in the UK: importers, agents, freight forwarders, or private individuals.

question: How do I apply for a repayment of import duties in the UK?
answer: You can apply using the Customs Declaration Service or Customs Handling of Import and Export Freight (CHIEF) online service, or by using form C285, depending on where you made your declaration.
title: How to Apply for Import Duty Repayment in the UK
description: A step-by-step guide on how to claim import duty repayment in the UK, including use of the C285 form and digital services.

question: What is the time limit for submitting a claim for repayment in the UK?
answer: The time limit for submitting a claim is 3 years for overpayments, 1 year for rejected imports, and 3 months for invalidation of a customs entry.
title: Import Duty Repayment Claim Time Limits in the UK
description: See the deadlines for submitting different types of import duty repayment claims in the UK and avoid missed refund opportunities.

question: What documents do I need to claim a duty repayment in the UK?
answer: You need documents such as the movement reference number (MRN), EORI number, commercial invoice, packing list, transport documents, and bank details.
title: Required Documents for UK Duty Repayment Claims
description: Get a checklist of documents needed for import duty repayment claims in the UK, including MRN, EORI, invoices, and more.

question: Can I apply for a repayment if I am VAT registered in the UK?
answer: If you are VAT registered, you must make an adjustment through your VAT return instead of using the C285 form or the online service.
title: Duty Repayment for VAT-Registered Businesses in the UK
description: Learn the correct procedure for UK VAT-registered businesses to reclaim import duty via their VAT return instead of standard forms.

question: What is a DDP shipment?
answer: DDP (Delivered Duty Paid) refers to shipments where the shipper delivers goods already cleared for importation, bearing all landed costs including import duty and VAT.
title: What Is a DDP Shipment? Delivered Duty Paid Explained
description: Understand the meaning of DDP shipments, where all import clearance, duty, and VAT are paid by the shipper for seamless delivery.

question: Can I reclaim import VAT if the goods are not sold?
answer: Yes, you can reclaim import VAT even if the goods are not sold, provided certain legal conditions are fulfilled, such as shipping goods for storage or clinical trials.
title: Can You Reclaim Import VAT on Unsold Goods?
description: Find out the legal conditions under which businesses can reclaim import VAT even if the goods remain unsold, such as for storage or clinical uses.

question: What are the requirements for import VAT refund in the UK?
answer: Requirements include having a GB EORI number, being a taxable person in your home country, and submitting the VAT refund application within the prescribed timeframe.
title: Requirements for Import VAT Refund in the UK
description: Learn what businesses need to qualify for an import VAT refund in the UK, including GB EORI registration and timely application submission.

question: How long does it take to receive a VAT refund in the UK?
answer: The UK tax authorities typically process VAT refund applications within 4 to 6 months, but this can vary depending on the complexity of the claim.
title: VAT Refund Processing Times in the UK
description: Discover the usual processing timeline of VAT refund applications in the UK and factors that could influence claim turnaround.

question: What is duty reclaim and how does it benefit my business?
answer: Duty reclaim is the process of recovering customs duties and taxes paid on imported goods that are subsequently re-exported. It benefits your business by maximizing refunds, simplifying processes, enhancing cash flow, and promoting sustainable operations.
title: What Is Duty Reclaim and Its Business Benefits?
description: Understand duty reclaim and how reclaiming customs duties on re-exported goods can enhance refunds, streamline operations, and boost your business's cash flow.

question: We import goods from China into the UK and subsequently re-export them. Are we eligible for a duty refund?
answer: Yes, there are a few options for this type of movement and depening on IOR in the UK, the goods and frequency of shiments. One condition is that the goods must not have been processed or changed in any ways during their stay in the UK
title: Duty Refund Eligibility for Re-Exported Goods in the UK
description: Find out if your business qualifies for duty refunds when re-exporting goods imported from China into the UK, including key eligibility conditions.

question: What is an ETSF in the UK?
answer: An ETSF (External Temporary Storage Facility) is a customs-approved location where goods can be stored temporarily before being re-exported or cleared for import. It allows for the deferral of customs duties and taxes until the goods are either re-exported or cleared for import into the EU.
title: What Is an ETSF in the UK? External Temporary Storage Facility Explained
description: Learn about ETSFs in the UK and how these customs-approved storage sites help defer duties and taxes on imported goods.

question: What is a Non-Resident Importer (NRI) in the US?
answer: A Non-Resident Importer (NRI) is a business or individual that imports goods into a country without having a physical presence in that country. NRIs are responsible for ensuring compliance with local customs regulations and may be required to appoint a customs broker or agent to handle the import process on their behalf.
title: What Is a Non-Resident Importer (NRI) in the US?
description: Explore the definition and responsibilities of a Non-Resident Importer (NRI) under US customs law, including compliance management and broker appointment.

question: Can a Non-Resident Importer (NRI) claim duty drawback in the US?
answer: Yes, a Non-Resident Importer (NRI) can claim duty drawback, provided they meet the necessary requirements and comply with local customs regulations.
title: Can NRIs Claim Duty Drawback in the US?
description: Find out if non-resident importers can access duty drawback in the US and the conditions for eligibility.

question: I sell goods online from EU to the US and ship them DDP directly to the end-user. Can I benefit from Duty Drawback if the seller returns the items
answer: Yes, you can benefit from Duty Drawback using this model. Some conditions apply, in particular with regards to the logistics model that you use. Contact our Trade Experts for more information by clicking here
title: Duty Drawback for EU to US DDP E-Commerce Returns
description: See how e-commerce sellers using DDP shipping from the EU to the US can qualify for duty drawback on returned goods and which conditions apply.

question: How much does a duty drawback service cost in the UK?
answer: In the UK,the cost is typically a competitive percentage of the duty recovered, depending on factors such as the duty recovery levels, statutory filing provision, and administrative resources required.
title: Duty Drawback Service Costs in the UK
description: Learn what UK duty drawback services typically cost, the basis for pricing, and which factors influence how much you pay.

question: If I use a FTZ or a bonded warehouse, can I use duty drawback?
answer: Yes you can. Duties are paid when goods leave the bonded facility or the FTZ. But the same duty drawback rule applies.
title: Using Duty Drawback with FTZs and Bonded Warehouses
description: Find out how duty drawback applies when storing goods in Free Trade Zones or bonded warehouses, and when duties are due.

question: Is there a difference in using a bonded warehouse vs a FTZ from a duty standpoint?
answer: The big distinction when goods get into FTZ, the applicable duty rate is the one in application when goods entered the US Bonded Warehouse, the duty rate is the one in effect when you exit the bonded warehouse.
title: Bonded Warehouse vs FTZ: Duty Implications Explained
description: Compare the duty calculation differences between using a bonded warehouse versus a Free Trade Zone (FTZ) for your imports in the US.

question: How did most importers try to mitigate section 301 in 2018?
answer: A combination of 4 actions: Take a hair cut: talk to suppliers and ask for a price decrease Reduce non essential expenses (travel, advertisement, events) Pass the cost on to the end customer (Longer Term) Find alternate sourcing opportunities (from China to India, Vietnam and Mexico)
title: How Importers Mitigated Section 301 Tariffs in 2018
description: Discover the main strategies US importers used in 2018 to cope with section 301 tariffs, including supplier negotiation and new sourcing.

question: What is the First Sale Rule?
answer: This rule allows importers to use the price paid for the goods in an earlier sale (often the first sale from the manufacturer to a middleman) rather than the price paid in the last sale (from the middleman to the importer) for the purpose of calculating customs duties. Contact us for more detail on applicability, requirements and documentation.
title: What Is the First Sale Rule for US Imports?
description: Learn how the First Sale Rule lets importers use an earlier transaction price for customs duty calculations and how to document eligibility.
